<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 193, 220, 208]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 215, 356, 232]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Pure Mathematics 2 (P2)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 259, 460, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 193, 907, 208]]<|/det|>
9709/21  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[784, 216, 907, 232]]<|/det|>
May/June 2011  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 238, 907, 253]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 320, 390, 338]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 351, 828, 367]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 367, 722, 383]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 384, 325, 400]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 400, 497, 416]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 416, 601, 433]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 447, 284, 463]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 463, 907, 495]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 494, 589, 510]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 510, 606, 526]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 540, 606, 556]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 556, 756, 572]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 572, 440, 588]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 588, 907, 619]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 425, 92]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(|3x + 4| = |2x + 5|.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 74, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 120, 96, 139]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 390, 139]]<|/det|>
A curve has parametric equations

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[366, 146, 631, 165]]<|/det|>
\[x = 3t + \sin 2t,\quad y = 4 + 2\cos 2t.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 172, 640, 192]]<|/det|>
Find the exact gradient of the curve at the point for which \(t = \frac{1}{6}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 173, 920, 191]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 219, 96, 237]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 230, 789, 422]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 440, 922, 492]]<|/det|>
The variables \(x\) and \(y\) satisfy the equation \(y = Kx^{m}\), where \(K\) and \(m\) are constants. The graph of \(\ln y\) against \(\ln x\) is a straight line passing through the points (0, 2.0) and (6, 10.2), as shown in the diagram. Find the values of \(K\) and \(m\), correct to 2 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 475, 920, 492]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 520, 96, 539]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 520, 393, 539]]<|/det|>
The polynomial \(\operatorname {f}(x)\) is defined by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[395, 545, 601, 565]]<|/det|>
\[\operatorname {f}(x) = 3x^{3} + ax^{2} + ax + a,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 572, 295, 590]]<|/det|>
where \(a\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 603, 151, 621]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 603, 603, 621]]<|/det|>
Given that \((x + 2)\) is a factor of \(\operatorname {f}(x)\), find the value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 603, 920, 621]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 632, 160, 651]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 632, 860, 651]]<|/det|>
When \(a\) has the value found in part (i), find the quotient when \(\operatorname {f}(x)\) is divided by \((x + 2)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 632, 920, 651]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 686, 96, 705]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 680, 626, 710]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}}\) when \(x = 4\) in each of the following cases:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 715, 153, 734]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 715, 280, 734]]<|/det|>
\(y = x\ln (x - 3)\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 715, 920, 734]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 744, 146, 763]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 744, 242, 763]]<|/det|>
\(y = \frac{x - 1}{x + 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 746, 920, 765]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 806, 96, 825]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 802, 146, 825]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 800, 341, 827]]<|/det|>
Find \(\int 4\mathrm{e}^{x}(3 + \mathrm{e}^{2x})\mathrm{d}x.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 806, 920, 825]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 850, 146, 870]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 848, 495, 888]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\int_{-\frac{1}{4}\pi}^{\frac{1}{4}\pi}(3 + 2\tan^{2}\theta)\mathrm{d}\theta = \frac{1}{2} (8 + \pi).\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 855, 920, 874]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 73, 156, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 650, 93]]<|/det|>
By sketching a suitable pair of graphs, show that the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 98, 551, 118]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{e}^{2x} = 14 - x^{2}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 126, 369, 144]]<|/det|>
has exactly two real roots.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 126, 920, 144]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 157, 151, 175]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 156, 692, 176]]<|/det|>
Show by calculation that the positive root lies between 1.2 and 1.3.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 157, 920, 176]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 188, 151, 207]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 188, 520, 207]]<|/det|>
Show that this root also satisfies the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 212, 571, 234]]<|/det|>
\[x = \textstyle {\frac{1}{2}}\ln (14 - x^{2}).\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 214, 918, 233]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 253, 151, 272]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 253, 920, 303]]<|/det|>
Use an iteration process based on the equation in part (iii), with a suitable starting value, to find the root correct to 2 decimal places. Give the result of each step of the process to 4 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 285, 920, 303]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 330, 96, 348]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 330, 148, 348]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 330, 920, 364]]<|/det|>
Express \(4 \sin \theta - 6 \cos \theta\) in the form \(R \sin (\theta - \alpha)\), where \(R > 0\) and \(0^\circ < \alpha < 90^\circ\). Give the exact value of \(R\) and the value of \(\alpha\) correct to 2 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 352, 920, 369]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 378, 153, 396]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 377, 615, 396]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(4 \sin \theta - 6 \cos \theta = 3\) for \(0^\circ \leqslant \theta \leqslant 360^\circ\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 378, 920, 396]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 408, 151, 426]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 408, 789, 426]]<|/det|>
Find the greatest and least possible values of \((4 \sin \theta - 6 \cos \theta)^2 + 8\) as \(\theta\) varies.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 408, 920, 426]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[433, 75, 564, 90]]<|/det|>
